translations.translation: Where are the two men going?
The two of them are going for meat.
Where are you going?
I'm going to get water.

notes: Note order -possibly focus first, then pronoun either side of the verb (keep the verbs together? or post-verbal topic?

translations.translation: Where are you from?
(I'm) from the big water.

notes: example - response to basic introduction question

sentences.transcription: mithi baduani ini/ bakarranyi marnngarra yundru

translations.translation: You have the ability to make a boomerang.

notes: Another example where the focus is first, then the verb, then the pronoun (maybe the focus is "make a boomerang"?)

translations.translation: No, (I) can't make it. (lit. "It (is) make-less.")

notes: Nice! Nominative on a nominalized verb

translations.translation: You(,) ask my brother.

notes: Imperative verb going first. Not sure if all examples like that - check.

sentences.transcription: murra nganytya gakudya marnngarra ingka bakarranyi

translations.translation: OK, my uncle will make you a boomerang.

notes: mura - better translation might be OK or "well" rather than "finished" based on examples like this.

translations.translation: I am not able to make a boomerang.

notes: Maybe literal trans is "no, I'm unable to make"

translations.translation: That dog is continuously barking.
The kids are all swimming in the water.
I feel hot.
I think I'll lie down here in the shade.
Over there.
Here.
A man (that one) is lying in the shade.
(It's?) late, I will lie down, I think.
I feel cold.

sentences.transcription: wina ngali barnrdirra winawarra ngali gulharra wiyilya

translations.translation: We will sit down close to the fire. [We will move close to sit close to the fire.]

sentences.transcription: dhilagala nhaniguru dhila bari/ gurru nhanha ngalingu gulparra

translations.translation: This cold wind is blowing, the two of us will build a windbreak.
I think we will light a fire.
That child is crying.
Why is that child crying?
That child ran.

notes: Check on -gali vs -nga for past tense.

translations.translation: He fell down and hurt his leg.

notes: Note relative order of -wa and past tense marker.
sure that the -na here is really accusative and shouldn't be a nominative instead?

sentences.transcription: mirlaani maltya galgurrigala/ ngalingu ngurra galirra nhungala

translations.translation: The sun is going down - late. The two of us make camp over here.

notes: maltya late adverb or adjective? any additional examples?

sentences.transcription: nhungalaguru bari ngalingu ngurra galirra burngalunga

translations.translation: I think the two of us will make camp over there at the gum tree.

notes: -guru should have a suffix marker I think

translations.translation: I think the two of us will sleep here.

sentences.transcription: wikarla mirla warlpalha ngali yanhthabarra ngali yanhthabarra

translations.translation: Tomorrow when the sun comes up the two of us will go on.

notes: ba as "away" vs ba as emphatic?
several other instances of ba + -ra (future) are glossed as EMPH, not 'away'

translations.translation: Tomorrow the two of us will go a long way.
Sit down in my camp.
The day after tomorrow stay - (then?) you will go away.
Hey, this is my meat here.

sentences.transcription: walya ingka nhaniguru nguthiani/ ngutyadhikarra nganha

translations.translation: This is not your meat, give it back to me.

sentences.transcription: murra ngathu inha ngutyadhikarra/ ingka nguthiani

translations.translation: OK, I will give you back your meat. [Finished, I will give it back to you / It is your meat.]
I thought this meat here was mine.
Don't pick up this man's stick. (It is) this man's.
This is my father's stick.
I lift this stone.
This is not heavy.
I am not able to lift up this stone.
I am lifting this one.
Will you lift this log?

sentences.transcription: ga ngathu nhanhaguru warlpabarra bilkaanha ingka

translations.translation: Yes, I will lift this log for you.
Come, the two of us will cross to the other side.
This water is not crossable. It is deep. [Cannot cross the water, deep.]
His father is coming.

sentences.transcription: dhuna-bari ngali wirarra burlilha nhanigurru ngakaani

translations.translation: The two of us will wait until the water falls. [The two of us will wait, the water will fall.]
My dog is good.

notes: example - another one with no copula

translations.translation: I'm going away.
Where are you going?
I'm going far away.
When will you return?
I will return the day after tomorrow.
When will the two of you return?
The two of us will return the day after tomorrow.
He will return the day after tomorrow.
Come, the two of us will go.
Look at the snake on the stone. [Look at it / The snake is on the stone.]
Where is the snake? I don't see (it).
That one on the stone by the gum tree.

sentences.transcription: ga murra ngathu nhadyagala nhanhagurru murnaanha

translations.translation: Yes, OK, I see the snake.
